And if you're going to search through a bag, at least let the person defend themselves. We even do that in court where someone could have murdered someone else!!!
 
 and back to the "adults are always right, you'll understand when you're older". That is the biggest pile of bull**** I've heard in a while. If there's one thing I've learned as I grew up (no I'm not all grown up yet, I realize that) is that parents aren't perfect. They do second-guess themselves, but ultimately they want what's best for their child. I used to think my parents were perfect. They knew where everything was in the house, what to do in any situation, what medicines to use when I was sick, etc. Now as I grow up and get to make more and more decisions for myself, I realize that parents aren't perfect, they make mistakes, and they second-guess themselves. For example my mom admitted to me that she thought about letting my little brother quit piano lessons when he screamed that he hated it, even just for her sake of not having to listen to it anymore and forcing him to play the piano. But she said she thought that in the future, he would thank her. Obviously this is a case of "you don't understand", but it can be explained. There's a difference between, "here's the reason, but you won't like it" and "we're older and you'll understand how we're always right when you're older".
 
 In my opinion, the parents of the original poster made a mistake. They over-reacted and thought it must have been her choice of friends. The problem though is, you're stuck, for better or worse, with the parents you have. This can't be changed, and unless they are abusing you, you have to put up with them for 4 more years (well maybe 3 plus however many months). And guess what? At that point you'll probably still need to depend on them for some things. I don't know what your plans are for after high school, but college is quite a bit of money (private colleges I've been looking at seem to be from $30,000 - $35,000. In-state state-funded colleges are a little under $10,000 a year). So unless you can come up with $40,000, you'll probably need a little help from your parents.
 
 So basically the lesson is that you should try to get along with your parents if you don't want to have several years of living hell. I don't know what your relationship is like but I would try to talk with them. Talk about how it started as a joke, but you got a little carried away (I assume that was the case). Explain how it was you who took the hat, not your friend, and you don't see why you are separated from a friend for an action that you did. See what happens, the worst thing that can happen is that she says "that's my final word, no arguing". Now hopefully you don't have that kind of mom, but if you do you can't really do anything about it, that's the way it is. At least she seems to let you go on the internet on your own, so that hints that maybe she's a bit understanding. Don't go complaining, go as a person and ask her to talk.
 
 
 And don't let her give you that bull**** about "you'll understand when you're older". I already gave you my theory, and I may be way off. But adults aren't THAT much different from kids. Yes there's a difference, but not so much that kids aren't able to understand adults. Ask her to explain why, and hopefully you can change her mind. But the real advice, is next time you think you're just playing around, think about what it must feel like to be in the other person's shoes. Would you like it if someone walked up to you and took your hat? I would think you were a bully if you did that to me, unless we were good friends. Most bullying is thought of as playing around by the person doing it, but that's not how the victim feels. I understand that you weren't thinking about that when you did it, and it just felt like harmless fun. But next time stop and think about what your actions do to other people. And I'm sure that's not how you want to be thought of, especially since you posted on this site.
